This design system serves as a set of organized tools, patterns & practices that work as the foundation for visitscotland.com.

Please be aware this design system is a work in progress and still in development stages where things are constantly changing therefore should not be used as the only reference.

We have created the look and feel of the visitscotland.com site using the principles of Brand Scotland as a base.

Primary palette

Our primary palette consists of the principal VisitScotland brand colours and neutrals.

Each colour has a suite of tints and shades to allow optimum flexibility while retaining brand identification. The neutral colours are used for the largest elements on the page, while the vibrant pinks and purples are used more sparingly to highlight specific elements.

 

<Color filterCategory="Primary" />

 

<Color filterCategory="Neutral" />

 

Secondary palette

Our secondary palette is used alongside the primary palette to complement and add depth. These are used sparingly to maintain their impact and not overwhelm functionality or imagery. They also have a suite of tints and shades to allow more flexibility.

 

<Color filterCategory="Secondary" />

 

Theme colours

These colours don’t represent brand, but indicate specific functions like warning, success etc.

 

<Color filterCategory="Theme colours" />

 

<Color filterCategory="Social Media Colours" />

 

Accessible colours

Colour combinations should have adequate contrast to meet WCAG 2.1 AA accessibility criteria. This will depend on the size of the text and/or graphical elements. Check colour contrast using any of the WCAG 2.1 recommended tools.

Fonts

We use the Source Sans Pro font for body content which is a free open source font developed by Google for use on screen. It has different weight options.

Download Source Sans Pro

We use Eveleth for headings which is a font owned and licenced to Visit Scotland by Yellow Design Studio.

For any queries please contact Mark Haddon at mark.haddon@visitscotland.com

 

Headings

The first heading on a page is an H1. There should only be one H1 per page.

H2 headings are used to distinguish different modules on a page. However, there are several exceptions:

  • Megalinks module [link tbc]
  • Long content module [link tbc]
  • Long content text only – multiple H2s allowed [link tbc]

These modules can be used without H2s. 

Heading levels should be in order. That means H1 is followed by an H2, an H2 is followed by an H2 or H3 and so on. Hierarchical headings are helpful for accessibility and help all users to understand your content. Search engines may make use of them to understand the content of your site.

All Headings apart from H6 are written in capital letters. H6 headings are written in sentence case. Full stops are not used in headings.

[insert demo]

Paragraphs

Body

The default paragraph font size used by the Design System is 18px on larger screens and 16px on smaller screens. 

[insert demo]

Leader text

Leader text is copy associated with an H1 or and H2 and is located below either of these headings. It is also often referred to as introductory copy and summarises the subsequent page content.

[insert demo]

Small copy

Small type should be used sparingly and when content is limited in space within a component, for example an image caption. This size is the same across all viewports

[insert demo]

Very small copy

Small type should be used sparingly and when content is limited in space within a component, for example the command to ‘Enlarge image’. This size is the same across all viewports

[insert demo]

Teaser

Teaser copy style is always associated with a list of images and is only used on viewports over 992px.

[insert demo]

Quote

Quote style copy is only used when associating a quote or a ‘pull-out’ with a larger paragraph of body copy. It is the same size across all viewports.

[insert demo]

Quote Attribution

Quote Attribution copy style is only used in association with a quote style copy block when that copy requires an attribution. In all cases it will inherit the standard body copy paragraph style, relevant to that viewport and the paragraph in which it is placed.

[insert demo]

 

 

Links

 

Default links

Link styling is pink (#AF056E) and underlined by default. If a link appears at the end of a sentence, the full stop should be outside the link. In all cases the link will inherit the standard body copy paragraph style, relevant to that viewport.

[insert demo]

Internal links

On user click, the link opens within the same browser tab.

[insert demo]

Exceptions

Within the Megalinks and Other things you might like modules, an arrow icon [insert icon] is displayed to the right of the text. The character styles of these links are specified in the relevant module pages.

[Insert relevant links to modules]

External links

External Link styling is pink (#AF056E) and underlined by default and is followed by a pink arrow icon [insert icon]. If a link appears at the end of a sentence, the full stop should be outside the link. In all cases the external link will inherit the standard body copy paragraph style, relevant to that viewport and the paragraph in which it is placed.

On user click, open the link within the same browser tab.

[insert demo]

Email Links

Make email addresses ‘mailto’ links (to bring up default email client with a subject heading related to the enquiry). No icon is required. 

Document links

Throughout the site, if there is a link to a document file, add the word ‘Download', file size and format to the end of the link text with brackets, to give users an indication of how much data will be used to download the file. For example “Wildlife of The Highlands eBrochure (download PDF 3MB)”. To the right of the text link, a download icon [insert icon]  is displayed.

The file format and size is displayed in consistent casing (for example all uppercase, e.g. PDF 3MB)

[insert demo]

Button CTA link

Button copy is always in full caps and is always the same size irrespective of viewport.

[insert demo]

Breadcrumb

All pages have a breadcrumb at the top of the page which is automatically generated and designed to help the user identify where they are on the website.

[insert demo]

List of Links

Introduce a list of links with a lead-in line or paragraph.

Link lists are not numbered or bulleted and are constructed from short complete statements. Lines do not end with punctuation as the links will refer directly to the headings of the pages to which they link.

Links to webpages should be a descriptive text link (not repeated generic text). Use text rather than the URL of the site e.g. the text link 'Corporate site', instead of https://www.visitscotland.org/ as the link text.

[insert demo]

 

Lists

Use lists to make blocks of text easier to read.

 

Bulleted list

Introduce bulleted lists with a lead-in line ending in a colon. Start each item with a lowercase letter, and do not use a full stop at the end.

[insert demo]

Numbered list

Use numbered lists instead of bulleted lists when the order of the items is important. You do not need to use a lead-in line for numbered lists. Items in a numbered list should end in a full stop, because each one should be a complete sentence.

[insert demo]

All our page layouts are created using a uniform grid system providing fundamental structure for creating consistent layouts.

The grid system makes it easier for users to browse multiple content types on a page and also provides a consistent framework for designers and developers to work together to build a page. 

All designs are created with a mobile-first approach, starting with the smallest viewport first then scaling up to the largest viewport.  

Columns

All viewports are broken up into a 12-column grid based on the Bootstrap framework. The grid flexes depending on the viewport size but the 12 columns are always maintained within it.

All page content sits in relation to these columns:

Gutter

The gutter is the space between each column. For all viewports, the gutter width is 12px on either side of a column (or 24px combined). This excludes the XS viewport which has 2px on either side of a column (or 4px combined). In general, elements should line up from the inner left gutter to the inner right gutter.

Images

Text with padding

In a browser it would look like this

Text without padding

In browser it would look like this

Page margin

The page margin is the total width outside the 12 columns. This changes depending on the viewport width, except for the XS viewport which has a fixed 10px on either side (20px page margin in total)

To calculate the page margin:

Page margin = (viewport width – container width) / 2

For example:

1200px – 1140px / 2 = 30px (width of each margin)

Breakpoints

Breakpoints are customisable widths that we use to design responsive user interfaces. By designing responsively to these widths, we can adapt our design to a range of different device sizes.

We have six breakpoints in our grid system and each breakpoint holds a max-width container with 12 equal columns. Note that at the smallest viewport (xs), there is no fixed width but the layout container becomes 100% wide.

Using the Grid in UI

Our component library includes the <vs-container>, <vs-col> and <vs-row> components so developers can easily wrap content in the desired grid elements.

For more information on the Bootstrap grid please see the documentation for Bootstrap and BootstrapVue.

The icons we use on the visitscotland.com site are a mix of Font Awesome and custom icons. 

Icons are visual symbols that represent objects, actions or commands. They are used to help users understand the purpose of a particular action, command or section. 

Most of our icons are sourced from FontAwesome to maintain consistency throughout the site. A few icon exceptions were designed internally to encompass uniquely Scottish ideas.  

Using Icons 

Generally, icons should be decorative and used alongside meaningful and relevant text labels to help users progress through the site. There may be some exceptions when space is limited, in which case, alternative icon text should be provided for screen readers.

 

Consider the surrounding space around an icon and ensure a minimum of 8px gap around it.

 

For icons used on top of an image, use the filled version of the icon so it's clear.

Accessibility in our design is at the core of what we do.

We want to ensure users feel included and valued and have the same quality of experience, therefore VisitScotland strives to make digital products universally accessible and useful to everyone. 

This page outlines some general best practices to follow when designing and building for our product. More specific rules may be found within individual component pages.  

 

Page Structure 

A consistent, clear page hierarchy helps users interact with and navigate the page. 

Heading levels should follow the correct hierarchy e.g. H1, H2, H3, H4 and they should have meaningful titles helps people understand the page and how sections relate to each other. Important information should be visible on the page and not hidden.  

Using semantic markup and correct HTML elements also helps to communicate structure and hierarchy of the page. Screen readers can read this and are informed what the element is and what it does. For example, use heading elements (e.g. H1) instead of styling a non-semantic element to look like a heading.  

 

Keyboard Navigation 

Some users may navigate the content with just a keyboard or another tool such as a screen reader. People should be able to navigate our digital products without a mouse.  

When tabbing through the page, all interactive elements should have a visible focus style and be accessible in a logical order reading left to right, top to bottom.  

ARIA tags should be used where appropriate to make elements more accessible to assistive technologies. (See below) 

<DoDoNot>
    <div slot="thingToDo">
        <p>This is a good suggestion, we'd recommend you go ahead with it</p>      
    </div>
    <div slot="thingToNotDo">
        <p>This is absolutely not acceptable, you should not do this </p>
        
    </div>
</DoDoNot>

Accessible Text 

Meaningful text helps people who use screen readers to understand the content. All text should be accessible whether its visible on the page or alternative text. 

Text should be clear and concise so users can navigate the content faster. Labels should be consistent throughout and describe what the element is doing. For example, we should not use “Find out more” but describe what will happen “Find more information about Edinburgh.” is much clearer. 

 

Multimedia  

For audio or video multimedia, provide an alternative means for the user to experience what is being conveyed through vision and sound. This might be done by clear easy-to-read captioning on a video or by providing a full transcript download. 

 

Use of Colour  

We comply with the WCAG AA Standards which should ensure colour combinations have adequate contrast. This means the contrast ratio between standard text and the background should be greater than or equal to 4.5:1 and 3:1 for large text and UI components. Check colour contrast using any of the WCAG 2.1 recommended tools. 

Use multiple visual clues for interactive or directive elements and not only colour to convey meaning. This may include use of illustrations, shape, strokes to help people who struggle to distinguish between colours. For example, error message could change stroke. 

 

Visually Hiding Elements 

Sometimes we may need to add visually hidden content for assistive technologies. This is useful when visual information or cues need to be described to non-visual users.  

For example, if using an icon only button, we would want to provide visually hidden text to ensure this icon is described by a screen reader. Use the .sr-only utility class to hide elements for all devices except screen readers.  

 

Use ARIA Roles & Attributes 

Where relevant, use the correct ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Application) roles and attributes to help assistive technologies understand the meaning of elements on the page. This will help users navigate the content and understand context.  

We must tell users if content has dynamically changed on the page, so the screen reader is aware of it. For more information, please see the WAI-ARIA Authoring Practices.  

 

Responsive Design 

We follow a Mobile First approach when designing for our products, allowing for the key features to be built for small screens first and progressively advancing the design for desktop users. This gives a better user experience and means our software is responsive across a range of different viewports, ensuring it fits the screens of different devices automatically.  

 

Users With No JavaScript 

To enable as many people to use our products as possible, we provide a fall-back option for all our interactive elements so the user can still find the information they are looking for.  

For example, when the JavaScript has been turned off in the browser, an Accordion component would not be able to be toggled. All Accordion items will be displayed with all tabs open and the toggle button hidden to allow all the content to be read.  

In some cases, it may not be possible to display without JavaScript. In this case, we will show a message to the users that this piece of functionality cannot be used without JavaScript.  

 

Testing for Accessibility  

Human interaction is the most reliable method to assess accessibility. Therefore, manual checks should be run alongside automated testing to ensure our components comply with WCAG 2.1 and the accessibility guidance outlined here.  

When writing production code, we should test for accessibility regularly using accessibility tools in the browser, assistive technologies such as a screen reader and using the interface with only a keyboard. For information on what assistive technologies to test with see testing with assistive technologies.

Imagery plays a significant part in the VisitScotland.com experience, they help us to showcase the beauty and character of Scotland, its unique landscape, people and traditions.

This section contains guidelines for producing, sourcing and using images on the VisitScotland.com estate. For more information on imagery please contact multimedia@visitscotland.com.

Illustrations are another visual tool used throughout the site to complement other types of content on the site. They are used sparingly and thoughtfully to add touches of playfulness and to convey concepts that don’t necessarily have a photographic equivalent. For more help with illustrations please contact brandhelp@visitscotland.com.  

Photography 

Aspect ratio

All photographs should have a standard aspect ratio of 3:2. 

Image dos and don’ts  

Do consider the context when choosing images.

<DoDoNot> 
<div slot="thingToDo"> 

<p>Do select images based on their intended context</p> 
</div>
 <div slot="thingToNotDo"> 


<p>Don't use images that don't work in their intended context</p> 
</div> 
</DoDoNot>

 

Don’t use plain text over/as part of an image.

<DoDoNot>
<div slot="thingToDo">

<p>Do use a solid background with adequate contrast behind text when using it on top of images.</p>
</div>
<div slot="thingToNotDo">

<p>Don’t use plain text over images.</p>
</div>
</DoDoNot>

 

Do make sure that all non-clickable images have a locator and use the appropriate image caption.

<DoDoNot>
<div slot="thingToDo">



<p>Do use the appropriate image caption for the image.</p>
</div>
<div slot="thingToNotDo">


<p>Don’t use inappropriate image caption for the image.</p>
</div>
</DoDoNot>

 

Note that within the Hero area, an image needs to be chosen that allows for the lower area of the image to be obscured.

<DoDoNot>
<div slot="thingToDo">

<p>Do select images that allows for the lower area to be obscured.</p>
</div>
<div slot="thingToNotDo">

<p>Don't use images that do not allow for the lower area to be obscured.</p>
</div>
</DoDoNot>

Credits and Descriptions 

At VisitScotland we give credit to our creators and use image descriptions where possible, apart from the card component image. 

<DoDoNot>
<div slot="thingToDo">

<p>Do use credits and image description on hero images likes this.</p>
</div>
<div slot="thingToNotDo">


<p>Don't use credits and image description on card images likes this..</p>
</div>
</DoDoNot>

Illustrations 

An illustration may be used to communicate, explain or add context to information or to help visualise data. They should be used sparingly and thoughtfully.

<DoDoNot>
<div slot="thingToDo">

<p>Do use illustrations sparingly and thoughtfully.</p>
</div>
<div slot="thingToNotDo">


<p>Don’t use illustrations that add unneccessary visual clutter.</p>
</div>
</DoDoNot>

Accessibility 

Images should have text alternatives to describe them for people using assistive technologies. Avoid using text on an image but include images that are useful and meaningful to the text on the page. Do not use moving or flashing images where possible.   

All images must have an alt text attribute and should succinctly describe the content of the image so it can be conveyed to people who cannot see it. Please refer to the image component page for guidance on how to use images.

For decorative images, the alt attribute must be present but can be left blank to avoid screen readers reading out the image URL. See the Web Accessibility Tutorials from W3C for more information on each type of image and what kind of alt text to include.   

Media Library 

At VisitScotland our media is sourced responsibly, and every media content created is accredited to the appropriate creator. We do not use unapproved media on the website. Visit our media library.

We use a spacing scale to define padding, margins and positions of our components.

Spacing between elements is important as it helps to create relationships and hierarchy between elements in the UI, whilst use of white space helps to break up the page to help a user understand the content.

Using our spacing system allows our pages to stay consistent and keeps a similar rhythm across all screens.

The spacing system

The system uses multiples of 8px in our designs with 4px spacing used for smaller adjustments. Tokens themselves do not change based on screen size but at some breakpoints, it may be necessary to jump up or down on the scale to fit the needs of the UI.

Example of spacing tokens in a design

Design tokens are master values that contain specific design variables, used to construct and maintain the design while it is constantly evolving. 

They are the visual design foundations of our design system and all the values we need, set in data, that can be reused throughout our components.

From colour, spacing, typography, opacity, animation etc, design tokens can represent anything from an RGB colour to a number value or setting a complex box shadow.

Using these instead of hard coded values helps to standardise our designs and ensure we stay consistent whilst the design system grows. It also allows us to have a faster hand-off process between design and UI development.
